qas.question: What is the study of the inside of plants?
What is the study of the outside of plants?
How are plants different from animals?

answers.text: primary cell wall composed of the polysaccharides cellulose

qas.question: Where do plants store their DNA?
Are the vacuoles of plant cells larger or smaller than animal cells?

context: <a0_0>Plant anatomy<a0_0/> is the study of the structure of plant cells and tissues, whereas <a1_0>plant morphology<a1_0/> is the study of their external form. All plants are multicellular eukaryotes, their DNA stored <a3_0>in nuclei<a3_0/>. The characteristic features of plant cells that distinguish them from those of animals and fungi include a <a2_0>primary cell wall composed of the polysaccharides cellulose<a2_0/>, hemicellulose and pectin,  <a4_0>larger<a4_0/> vacuoles than in animal cells and the presence of plastids with unique photosynthetic and biosynthetic functions as in the chloroplasts. Other plastids contain storage products such as starch (amyloplasts) or lipids (elaioplasts). Uniquely, streptophyte cells and those of the green algal order Trentepohliales divide by construction of a phragmoplast as a template for building a cell plate late in cell division.
